awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research: Ocean Salinity as a predictor of US hydroclimate extremes
awd_abstract_narration:
Water availability is a fundamental necessity for society. As the largest moisture reservoir and ultimate moisture source, water from the oceans sustains terrestrial precipitation and is thus key to understanding variability in the water cycle on land. Floods and droughts represent extremes of the water cycle that have enormous consequences for society. In recent years Western drought has led to billions of dollars of agricultural losses and extensive wildfires, while floods produced similar losses in the South, Midwest and East of the US. They are caused by an excess or deficit of moisture exported from ocean to land.  Moisture evaporating from the ocean surface is the ultimate source for terrestrial precipitation. Thus, the availability of the oceanic moisture supply modulates the severity of hydroclimate extremes on land. As moisture exits the ocean, it leaves a signature in sea surface salinity. Recent studies have provided remarkable new evidence that salinity can be utilized as a skillful predictor of precipitation in the US Midwest, Southwest and other regions. The salinity precursors significantly outperform temperature-based predictors, especially in the years with heavy precipitation or exceptional drought.  Thus, sea surface salinity has great potential to provide a transformative improvement to seasonal forecasts of US hydroclimate extremes. This project will develop the scientific basis for a drought and flood early warning system for the US based on these new insights into the predictive potential of ocean salinity and the expanding salinity monitoring system that uses both in-situ measurements and satellites. This will lead to a number of societal benefits: lives saved and property preserved from wildfires and floods; improved crop yields resulting from more accurate seasonal rainfall forecasts; national security advances realized by better anticipation of destabilized regions affected by drought or flood crises; and more accurate forecasting of energy demand and the impact of water shortages on power plants. Several undergraduate students will have the opportunity to gain valuable research experience, and thus the project will help to train the next generation of climate scientists. Project findings will also be incorporated into graduate courses taught through the MIT/WHOI joint program and at Duke University, and the knowledge will be disseminated to the general public. 

The processes that produce the newly identified relationships between extreme precipitation and sea surface salinity will be explored. Daily precipitation data and a Bayesian statistical framework will be used to sample the extreme events in the US. Based on the Bayesian inference, the pre-season salinity precursors will be explored and mechanisms by which the water cycle generates the salinity signatures determined by calculating atmospheric moisture fluxes and the terms in the surface salinity budget. In addition, the oceanic moisture flux onto land will be tracked, and the processes assessed by which extremes develop through the moisture supply and/or energy redistribution in the atmospheric column. Machine-learning algorithms to predict extremes using the sea surface salinity precursors will be developed and applied. Novel approaches will be used in this project, including the use of Bayesian statistics to identify the optimal sea surface salinity and temperature predictors for rainfall extremes, analysis of the oceanic salinity budget to identify the driving atmospheric variables, analysis of the atmospheric circulations that transport water from ocean to land, and the development of machine learning algorithms to provide optimal seasonal predictions of extreme drought or floods.

por.por_cntn:
Floods and droughts represent extremes of the water cycle that have enormous consequences for society. They are caused by an excess or deficit of moisture exported from ocean to land. Moisture evaporating from the ocean surface is the ultimate source for terrestrial precipitation. Thus, the availability of the oceanic moisture supply modulates the severity of hydroclimate extremes on land. As moisture exits the ocean, it leaves a signature in sea surface salinity. Hence, ocean salinity can be utilized as a skillful predictor of precipitation in the U.S. and elsewhere. The ocean salinity precursors significantly outperform temperature-based predictors, especially in years with heavy precipitation or exceptional drought. The overarching goal of this project has thus been to explore the processes that produce the newly identified relationship between precipitation and oceanic moisture source, as manifest in salinity, and then apply the salinity precursors for predicting terrestrial rainfall, including extremes.

For U.S. hydroclimate, several studies (Liu et al. 2018; Li et al. 2022) successfully used ocean salinity as a precursor for terrestrial rainfall. Ocean salinity can skillfully explain variability in winter precipitation patterns in the Southwest U.S., with salinity-based models outperforming traditional sea surface temperature-based climate predictors (Liu et al. 2018). It was shown that ocean salinity in the tropical Pacific and subtropical North Atlantic equally contribute to skillful predictions of U.S. Midwest heavy rain a season ahead. Skillful prediction from ocean salinity is realized through tropical-extratropical teleconnections and local soil moisture feedback, improving Midwest heavy rainfall forecasts substantially, complementing existing ocean temperature-based frameworks (Li et al. 2022).

Extreme precipitation events in other regions around the world, such as in the Yangtze River Valley in China (Zeng et al. 2019) and across Australia (Rathore et al. 2020, 2021), could also be linked to excess moisture export and resultant salinity signatures in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Demonstrating the utility of ocean salinity as a proxy for Australian rainfall on seasonal to interannual timescales, characteristic patterns of salinity in the Indian and Pacific Oceans to the north of Australia were identified (Rathore et al. 2020). Using a machine learning approach, improved forecast skill 1-2 seasons ahead of summertime rainfall over northeastern Australia was obtained when including salinity-based indices in addition to those focused on traditional climate modes of variability (e.g., El Nino-Southern Oscillation); the improved skill was also apparent for extreme flood events across northeastern Australia in recent decades (Rathore et al. 2021). An amplification of the hydrological cycle is also apparent from ocean salinity changes, as highlighted in a review article for the Indian Ocean region (Ummenhofer et al. 2021) and for the Amazon river plume (Liang et al. 2020).

The project has important implications for linking oceanic moisture sources with terrestrial moisture sinks, with ocean salinity as the key metric. The demonstrated utility of ocean salinity as a skillful predictor for rainfall on land is hence of interest to the terrestrial component of the hydrological cycle, including for water resource management, seasonal forecasting, and weather predictions.

So far, the project led to a series of peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations (8 papers, 21 conference talks/posters), many of which with involvement of students and early-career researchers. This project allowed for educational opportunities for (under)graduate students to gain valuable hands-on experiences in interdisciplinary research in the field of atmospheric science, oceanography, climate dynamics, and machine learning at WHOI, including one topically-related honors thesis at their home institution. One graduate student and two postdoctoral researchers have been supported partially by this grant. A challenge for k-12 students on extreme weather events and the role of the ocean in the hydrological cycle reached ~70,000 students around the world. The project also provided opportunities for art-science collaborations with multiple pieces of artwork showcased at art exhibitions to communicate project findings to a broader audience. Furthermore, results from this project received national and international media coverage in print, online, and TV outlets.
